In the world it is becoming a difficult venture indeed to instill a sense of responsibility and accountability in our youth. Persuading someone to do something they may not initially want to, and which they are not legally bound to do is very difficult. Unfortunately it is common place to compromise an intangible moral obligation to further one's own agenda or to appease one's wants. It would appear as though the admiration that would once adhere to the "man for all seasons" has turned to the attitude that the example of Sir Thomas More is outdated and impractical. Too many people have forgotten or simply neglect the implicit consequences associated with exercising freedom in making choices. I think it would be appropriate to apply the phrase and accompanying principle "There's no such thing as a free lunch" to the concept that "there's no such thing as a free choice." 
 
 The government is arranged such that it cannot through conventional means legislate morality. The idea of government mandating, or even promoting, the values it seems fit, as was done in ancient Rome and as the Puritans believed it should, has been proved not viable. The government may however pass laws with moral tones which are created to protect a person from abusing their liberty to the extent of negatively impacting another's. For example, there is no law that forbids taking the life of another individual simply because it is morally wrong to do so. There can and is, however, a law forbidding murder because to kill someone would be infringing on their right to live and enjoy their constituted freedoms. So we see that we have the right to establish and live by what ever principles we desire and deem fit so long as our actions do not restrict the liberties of someone else.
 
 Laws that deal with aspects of personal relationships are difficult to establish as well as enforce. Part of the reason this is true is because in a relationship both individuals involved allow one another to take part in personal areas of their lives. In such a situation the individual is willing to trade some of their privacy when entering into the relationship for the things that they want to get from it. In a relationship where intercourse mutually takes place couples may make whatever decision they would like without any legal ramification so long as their activities do not inhibit the freedoms of any others. When a couple engages in intercourse they must be accountable for the potential outcome of conception and pregnancy. If an adult were to drink and become angry to the point of abusing his child, would the child be held responsible for the abuse that took place? Of course not. If such a question is so absurd why is it that two adults, or minors behaving as adults, can end the development of a child to avoid the consequences of an action they willfully took part in? 
 
 There are of course situations where the opinion of an accredited physician would expectedly be in favor of aborting a pregnancy. When I spoke of intercourse and accountability I used the word "willfully" because someone forced to have sex who becomes pregnant could not be expected to carry the child. Also, a baby incestuously conceived would fall under the same consideration. In addition, if the life and therefore liberty of the mother was threatened due to complications with the child a medical counsel would agree the mother would be justified in having an abortion. In cases such as these where the women has already had to endure much emotional and physical hardship the resolve of the ill fated pregnancy should be made to be as easy as possible. 
 
 There are very few situations where there can be a predetermined solution to an issue that will justly contend with every case that faces it. It would not be right or appropriate to make laws forbidding abortion in every circumstance. It is wrong, not only morally but ethically, to evade the responsibilities that accompany the freedom our country affords us in terminating the development of a life that began with an action and a choice we made. If the mother so chooses, adoption is available and often auspicious to the child. The right to life of a developing infant is as deserved as any persons already born now, and though no amount of time in life is guaranteed, at the very least the opportunity to chance growing and living against the odds of miscarriage or involuntary abortion should be.
